text:
“Happy Birthday to you, happy birthday to
you. Happy birthday dear…”

Jessica. She just turned 23 – well, so she
thinks. Her birth certificate gives her age

on paper, but physically her body parts are
all different ages. Yours too. For example,

the outer layer of your skin regenerates itself
every two weeks. Even urban legend says the
human body replaces itself every 7 years.
So… how old are you, really?

To work this out we need to travel back in
time. It’s 1945 and the first atomic bomb
is detonated at a test site in New Mexico.

In the blast, something called Carbon-14 is
emitted. Remember that the regular Carbon

atom has 6 protons and 6 neutrons. It's sometimes
called Carbon 12. Carbon-14 has 6 protons

and 8 neutrons–it kind of takes two neutrons
from nitrogen when they slam together in the
explosion.

It’s a small difference, but enough that
scientists can measure.

Carbon-14 occurs naturally in trace amounts,
but nuclear weapons testing until 1963 meant

there was a lot more in the atmosphere. Scientists
measure the amount of 14C in the atmosphere

every year and there’s still some hanging
around from the 50s and 60s.

Okay, you may be asking yourself what 14C
has to do with you. Well, it tends to hang

around in the air, it dissolves into oceans
and ends up in plants and our food. Somehow
it will make its way inside of you.

But carbon-14 isn’t harmful to us, so our
body starts to use it just like it uses regular

carbon atoms. Our bodies sub in 14C to build
our cells, proteins and even our DNA.

Because the amount of 14C in the atmosphere
changes every year, scientists discovered

how to date your organs by looking at the
amount of 14C in them. It’s carbon dating,

the same method scientists used to figure
out the age of the Dead Sea Scrolls and when

the woolly mammoth became extinct. To date
humans, it was labelled bomb-pulse dating.

And it turns out not many of your body parts
are actually as old as you. Your colon cells

are four days young and remember that outer
layer of your skin? It’s about two weeks
old.

By using bomb-pulse dating, scientists in
Sweden worked out your fat cells have a lifespan

of 10 years. And many of your brain cells
– called neurons – regenerate too.

One study found that in a 90 year old brain,
the neurons in the hippocampus, the memory
centre, were only 20-30 years old.

And this is the real discovery of bomb-pulse
dating. We used to think the neurons you were

born with were the ones you died with. In
certain areas of your brain they have the
ability to regenerate.

There is one part of your body that’s been
with you since birth – your cortical neurons.

They make up your cerebral cortex, this outer
layer of your brain. It’s responsible for

your higher functions, like thought, consciousness,
language and your perception of the world
around you.

The reason we know your cortical neurons have
been with you your whole live is because of

18 years of atomic bomb testing. Wherever
you are in the world and however old you are,

you have little pieces of that world history
living inside of you.

Carbon-14 from bomb pulses is actually part
of your DNA.

So when you celebrate your next trip around
the sun, wish your cortical neurons a big

happy birthday. They’re one part of you
that’s really as old as you claim to be.
